page.title: 07THE LEEDS/LIVERPOOL CANAL
page.content: The canal is different from rivers or lakes because it is man-made. It was built to carry goods because the roads were dangerous and bumpy. The Leeds/Liverpool Canal is 127 miles long, there are 84 locks and 594 bridges. Mills were very often built along the banks of the canal. In Blackburn the mills were built here so that the cotton manufactured could easily be loaded on to the barges and exported. It was quicker for goods to travel by barge because the canals were built in a straight line and were smoother than the roads. Today, in Blackburn, the canal is only used by pleasure craft. Many old barges have been converted into house boats for use at weekends and during holidays.
